items.title: Wembanyama returns to help Spurs to NBA Cup final
items.summary: Victor Wembanyama returns from injury for the San Antonio Spurs and helps them reach the NBA Cup final with a win against the Oklahoma City Thunder.

items.title: Why Sunderland v Newcastle means so much
items.summary: Sunderland and Newcastle United will meet in the Premier League on Sunday for the first time in nearly a decade as "two worlds collide".

items.title: Cordina closer to two-weight title dream after win
items.summary: Former super-featherweight world champion Joe Cordina should emerge as the WBO's number one lightweight contender after dominating Gabriel Flores Jr in California.

items.title: 'The game that really matters' - pundits on Tyne-Wear derby
items.summary: Football Focus pundits Stephen Warnock and Ashley Williams look ahead to Sunday's Tyne-Wear derby between Newcastle and Sunderland.

items.title: No batting changes for vital Ashes Test - McCullum
items.summary: Head coach Brendon McCullum says England are unlikely to make changes to their batting line-up for the crucial third Ashes Test in Adelaide.

items.title: Goodbye - but only for now? Salah signs off as questions remain
items.summary: Mohamed Salah's return to the Liverpool side shows boss Arne Slot is prepared to move on - but questions still remain.

items.title: A new AAA Alien game is reportedly in the works
items.summary: If Alien: Romulus reawakened your appetite for the iconic sci-fi franchise, the good news is that a promising video game could be on the way. According to an Insider Gaming report, a new game for the Alien franchise is back in development. The report's sources mentioned that the single-player game â€¦

items.title: West Ham set sights on Sargent - Sunday's gossip
items.summary: Josh Sargent is a target for West Ham, Manchester City are prepared to sell a trio to boost their January spending, Ibrahima Konate is attracting interest from Europe, plus more.

items.title: Why Twilio Segment moved from microservices back to a monolith
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Saracens go top of PWR as Wafer makes Quins debut
items.summary: Ireland's Aoife Wafer makes her debut for Harlequins in their PWR win against Sale, while Saracens beat Exeter to go top of the table.

items.title: Sharks and rays gain landmark protections as nations move to curb international trade
items.summary: Gov'ts agree to ban or restrict international trade in shark meat, fins, and other products.
items.body: For the first time, global governments have agreed to widespread international trade bans and restrictions for sharks and rays being driven to extinction. Last week, more than 70 shark and ray species, including oceanic whitetip sharks, whale sharks, and manta rays, received new safeguards under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. The convention, known as CITES, is a United Nations treaty that requires countries to regulate or prohibit international trade in species whose survival is threatened. Sharks and rays are closely related species that play similar roles as apex predators in the ocean, helping to maintain healthy marine ecosystems. They have been caught and traded for decades, contributing to a global market worth nearly $1 billion annually, according to Luke Warwick, director of shark and ray conservation at Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS), an international nonprofit dedicated to preserving animals and their habitats. Read full article Comments

items.title: OpenAI built an AI coding agent and uses it to improve the agent itself
items.summary: "The vast majority of Codex is built by Codex," OpenAI told us about its new AI coding agent.
items.body: With the popularity of AI coding tools rising among some software developers, their adoption has begun to touch every aspect of the process, including the improvement of AI coding tools themselves. In interviews with Ars Technica this week, OpenAI employees revealed the extent to which the company now relies on its own AI coding agent, Codex , to build and improve the development tool. â€œI think the vast majority of Codex is built by Codex, so itâ€™s almost entirely just being used to improve itself,â€ said Alexander Embiricos, product lead for Codex at OpenAI, in a conversation on Tuesday. Codex, which OpenAI launched in its modern incarnation as a research preview in May 2025, operates as a cloud-based software engineering agent that can handle tasks like writing features, fixing bugs, and proposing pull requests. The tool runs in sandboxed environments linked to a userâ€™s code repository and can execute multiple tasks in parallel. OpenAI offers Codex through ChatGPTâ€™s web interface, a command-line interface (CLI), and IDE extensions for VS Code, Cursor , and Windsurf . Read full article Comments

items.title: Google Translate expands live translation to all earbuds on Android
items.summary: Expanded live translation will come to iOS in the coming months.
items.body: Google has increasingly moved toward keeping features locked to its hardware products, but the Translate app is bucking that trend. The live translate feature is breaking out of the Google bubble with support for any earbuds you happen to have connected to your Android phone. The app is also getting improved translation quality across dozens of languages and some Duolingo-like learning features. The latest version of Googleâ€™s live translation is built on Gemini and initially rolled out earlier this year. It supports smooth back-and-forth translations as both on-screen text and audio. Beginning a live translate session in Google Translate used to require Pixel Buds, but that wonâ€™t be the case going forward. Google says a beta test of expanded headphone support is launching today in the US, Mexico, and India. The audio translation attempts to preserve the tone and cadence of the original speaker, but itâ€™s not as capable as the full AI-reproduced voice translations you can do on the latest Pixel phones . Google says this feature should work on any earbuds or headphones, but itâ€™s only for Android right now. The feature will expand to iOS in the coming months. Apple does have a similarâ€¦

items.title: Ukrainians sue US chip firms for powering Russian drones, missiles
items.summary: Lawsuits may force Intel, AMD, and Texas Instruments to do more to control chip supply chains.
items.body: Dozens of Ukrainian civilians filed a series of lawsuits in Texas this week, accusing some of the biggest US chip firms of negligently failing to track chips that evaded export curbs. Those chips were ultimately used to power Russian and Iranian weapon systems, causing wrongful deaths last year. Their complaints alleged that for years, Texas Instruments (TI), AMD, and Intel have ignored public reporting, government warnings, and shareholder pressure to do more to track final destinations of chips and shut down shady distribution channels diverting chips to sanctioned actors in Russia and Iran. Putting profits over human lives, tech firms continued using â€œhigh-riskâ€ channels, Ukrainian civiliansâ€™ legal team alleged in a press statement , without ever strengthening controls. Read full article Comments

items.title: Scientists built an AI co-pilot for prosthetic bionic hands
items.summary: Managing each finger separately can, with the right sensors, ease control issues.
items.body: Modern bionic hand prostheses nearly match their natural counterparts when it comes to dexterity, degrees of freedom, and capability. And many amputees who tried advanced bionic hands apparently didnâ€™t like them. â€œUp to 50 percent of people with upper limb amputation abandon these prostheses, never to use them again,â€ says Jake George, an electrical and computer engineer at the University of Utah. The main issue with bionic hands that drives users away from them, George explains, is that theyâ€™re difficult to control. â€œOur goal was making such bionic arms more intuitive, so that users could go about their tasks without having to think about it,â€ George says. To make this happen, his team came up with an AI bionic hand co-pilot. Micro-management issues Bionic handsâ€™ control problems stem largely from their lack of autonomy. Grasping a paper cup without crushing it or catching a ball mid-flight appear so effortless because our natural movements rely on an elaborate system of reflexes and feedback loops. When an object you hold begins to slip, tiny mechanoreceptors in your fingertips send signals to the nervous system that make the hand tighten its grip. This all happens within 60 to â€¦

items.title: Man shocks doctors with extreme blood pressure, stroke from energy drinks
items.summary: His blood pressure was 254/150. Readings of 180/120 are considered an emergency.
items.body: Sometimes, downing an energy drink can feel like refueling your battery. But with too much, that jolt can turn into a catastrophic surge that fries the wiring and blows a fuse. That was the unfortunate and alarming case for a man in the UK several years ago, according to a case report this week in BMJ Case Reports. The man, who was in his 50s and otherwise healthy, showed up at a hospital after the entire left side of his body abruptly went numb and he was left with clumsy, uncoordinated muscle movements (ataxia). His blood pressure was astonishingly high, at 254/150 mm Hg. For context, a normal reading is under 120/80, while anything over 180/120 is considered a hypertensive crisis , which is a medical emergency. The man had suffered a mild stroke, and his extremely high blood pressure was an obvious factor. But why his blood pressure had reached stratospheric heights was far less obvious to his doctors, according to the retrospective case report written by Martha Coyle and Sunil Munshi of Nottingham University Hospital. Read full article Comments

items.title: Apple loses its appeal of a scathing contempt ruling in iOS payments case
items.summary: But Sweeney warns iOS devs are still afraid of "totally illegal" retaliation by Apple.
items.body: Back in April, District Court Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers delivered a scathing judgment finding that Apple was in â€œwillful violationâ€ of her 2021 injunction intended to open up iOS App Store payments. That contempt of court finding has now been almost entirely upheld by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, a development that Epic Gamesâ€™ Tim Sweeney tells Ars he hopes will â€œdo a lot of good for developers and start to really change the App Store situation worldwide, I think.â€ The ruling , signed by a panel of three appellate court judges, affirmed that Appleâ€™s initial attempts to charge a 27 percent fee to iOS developers using outside payment options â€œhad a prohibitive effect, in violation of the injunction.â€ Similarly, Appleâ€™s restrictions on how those outside links had to be designed were overly broad; the appeals court suggests that Apple can only ensure that internal and external payment options are presented in a similar fashion. The appeals court also agreed that Apple acted in â€œbad faithâ€ by refusing to comply with the injunction, rejecting viable, compliant alternatives in internal discussions. And the appeals court was also not convinced by Appleâ€™s process-focused argumentâ€¦

items.title: Senator endorses discredited doctorâ€™s book that claims chemical treats autism, cancer
items.summary: Safety experts advise those who handle chlorine dioxide to work in well-ventilated spaces, wear gloves.
items.body: For years, Sen. Ron Johnson has been spreading conspiracy theories and misinformation about COVID-19 and the safety of vaccines. Heâ€™s promoted disproven treatments for COVID-19 and claimed, without evidence, that athletes are â€œdropping dead on the fieldâ€ after getting the COVID-19 vaccination. Now the Wisconsin politician is endorsing a book by a discredited doctor promoting an unproven and dangerous treatment for autism and a host of ailments: chlorine dioxide, a chemical used for disinfecting and bleaching. The book is â€œ The War on Chlorine Dioxide: The Medicine that Could End Medicine â€ by Dr. Pierre Kory, a critical care specialist who practiced in Wisconsin hospitals before losing his medical certification for statements advocating using an antiparasite medication to treat COVID-19. The action, heâ€™s said, makes him unemployable , even though he still has a license. Read full article Comments

items.title: Investors commit quarter-billion dollars to startup designing â€œGigaâ€ satellites
items.summary: "If we build these platforms well, we get to ask new questions about what's possible in orbit."
items.body: A startup established three years ago to churn out a new class of high-power satellites has raised $250 million to ramp up production at its Southern California factory. The company, named K2 , announced the cash infusion on Thursday. K2â€™s Series C fundraising round was led by Redpoint Ventures, with additional funding from investment firms in the United States, the United Kingdom, and Germany. K2 has now raised more than $400 million since its founding in 2022 and is on track to launch its first major demonstration mission next year, officials said. K2 aims to take advantage of a coming abundance of heavy- and super-heavy-lift launch capacity, with SpaceXâ€™s Starship expected to begin deploying satellites as soon as next year. Blue Originâ€™s New Glenn rocket launched twice this year and will fly more in 2026 while engineers develop an even larger New Glenn with additional engines and more lift capability. items.summary: Sick of smart TVs? Here are your best options.
items.body: Smart TVs can feel like a dumb choice if youâ€™re looking for privacy, reliability, and simplicity. Todayâ€™s TVs and streaming sticks are usually loaded up with advertisements and user tracking , making offline TVs seem very attractive. But ever since smart TV operating systems began making money, â€œdumbâ€ TVs have been hard to find. In response, we created this non-smart TV guide that includes much more than dumb TVs. Since non-smart TVs are so rare, this guide also breaks down additional ways to watch TV and movies online and locally without dealing with smart TVsâ€™ evolution toward software-centric features and snooping. items.summary: "That is the moment an IPO suddenly came into play."
items.body: Welcome to Edition 8.22 of the Rocket Report! The big news this week concerns the decision by SpaceX founder Elon Musk to take the company public, via IPO, sometime within the next 12 to 18 months. Musk confirmed this after Ars published a story on Wednesday evening. This understandably raises questions about whether a future SpaceX will be committed more to AI data centers in space or Mars settlement. However, one of the companyâ€™s founding employees, Tom Mueller, said this could benefit the companyâ€™s Mars plans. Clearly this is something weâ€™ll be following closely. As always, we welcome reader submissions , and if you donâ€™t want to miss an issue, please subscribe using the box below (the form will not appear on AMP-enabled versions of the site). Each report will include information on small-, medium-, and heavy-lift rockets as well as a quick look ahead at the next three launches on the calendar. Avio will build solid rocket motors in Virginia . The governor of Virginia, Glenn Youngkin, announced Wednesday that Avio USA has selected his state to produce solid rocket motors for defense and commercial space propulsion purposes. items.title: Housemarque's Saros is delayed to April 30
items.summary: PlayStation had said on X that it would have news about Saros at The Game Awards, and unfortunately, fans excited for the new Housemarque project will need to wait a little longer to get their hands on it. The game has been delayed from its planned March release. But there's only a short time untilâ€¦

items.title: Star Wars: Galactic Racer is a podracing game set for 2026

Star Wars: Galactic Racer is a podracing (and speeder racing) game from Fuse Games, a studio established in 2023 by former Burnout and Need for Speed developers. It's scheduled to hit PS5, Xbox Series Xâ€¦

items.summary: So there's good news and bad news about the highly anticipated Exodus coming out of The Game Awards this year. The good news is that there's a fresh trailer showcasing more of the game. The bad news is that the game won't be out until early 2027. The game was originally announced two years ago (alsâ€¦

items.title: Lara Croft will return in Tomb Raider: Catalyst and a new remake
items.summary: The last mainline Tomb Raider game was 2018â€™s Shadow of the Tomb Raider, and after spending a few years in video game purgatory, Lara Croft is coming back in two new games. At The Game Awards 2025, Amazon Game Studios announced that Tomb Raider: Legacy of Atlantis will reimagine of one of the heroâ€™â€¦

items.title: Star Wars: Fate of the Old Republic announced as a KOTOR spiritual successor
items.summary: Original KOTOR director Casey Hudson returns to Star Wars with new studio Arcanaut.
items.body: Over two decades after the release of Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II , a new project described as a â€œspiritual successorâ€ to that seminal RPG series was announced at The Game Awards Thursday night. Star Wars: Fate of the Old Republic will be a collaboration between Lucasfilm Games and Arcanaut Studios, a new development house being launched by original KOTOR director Casey Hudson. Hudson, who will serve as director on the new game, said in an interview with StarWars.com that he has remained in contact with Lucasfilm since the KOTOR days, in the hopes of being able to collaborate in the Star Wars universe again. â€œIt took the right conditions to get everything to line up,â€ he told the site. Calling KOTOR â€œone of the defining experiences of my career,â€ Hudson said he wants to â€œexplore a contemporary visionâ€ of the Star Wars universe and â€œdeliver on the combination of player agency and immersion in Star Warsâ€ that defined the original games. As director on the upcoming game, Hudson said he sees his role as â€œto gather and shape a cohesive vision that the entire team contributes to. Ensuring that everyone shares that vision and understands their part in creating it is criticaâ€¦

items.title: The devs of SOMA are back with a spiritual successor called Ontos
items.summary: Frictional Games is back with a new game that looks primed to carry on the studio's tradition of excellence in horror. It's called Ontos, and it's slated to launch on PC, PlayStation and Xbox next year. The trailer debuted during The Game Awards 2025. The company's past projects include Amnesia: Thâ€¦

items.summary: Remedy Entertainment's Control is a bizarre yet totally captivating action game that feels like Die Hard by way of David Lynch. InControl: Resonant, players step into the role of the original game's most enigmatic and unsettling characters for their own jaunt through a 'new-weird' world outside Theâ€¦

Two years after taking home the Game of the Year prize for Baldurâ€™s Gate III at The Game Awards, the developer popped up again at the 2025 edition of the ceremony to announce its upcoming project, which is the next entry in the Divinity series. Siâ€¦

We'll often get updates on games that weâ€¦

It stars a hero rarely seen in video games, an elderly woman, and it has gorgeous storybook-style art in a lush fantasy setting. Itâ€™s a single-player puzzle platformer, it relies on wordless storytelling and the woman, â€¦

It's a brand new action role-playing game that will be directed by Casey Hudson, who previously headed up several notable BioWare games you probably know like Mass Effect and Star Wars: Knightâ€¦

items.summary: Capcomâ€™s long, long-delayed sci-fi shooter Pragmata finally has a release date. Itâ€™s headed your way on April 24, 2026 on Steam, PS5, Xbox Series X/S and â€” as Capcom confirmed in a trailer at The Game Awards â€” Nintendo Switch 2. You donâ€™t have to wait another four months to try it out, though. A gaâ€¦

items.title: Bradley the Badger looks like Wreck-It Ralph as a real video game
items.summary: A lot of trailers drop during The Game Awards, but the comedy of Bradley the Badger stood out from the pack. The conceit is similar to Wreck-It Ralph. Bradley, the protagonist of a fictional platforming series, is suddenly transported into the worlds of other unfinished video games; the trailer shoâ€¦

items.title: Runway claims its GWM-1 â€œworld modelsâ€ can stay coherent for minutes at a time
items.summary: Runway joins a competitive field alongside Google, Nvidia, and others.
items.body: AI company Runway has announced what it calls its first world model, GWM-1. Itâ€™s a significant step in a new direction for a company that has made its name primarily on video generation, and itâ€™s part of a wider gold rush to build new frontier of models as large language models and image and video generation move into a refinement phase, no longer an untapped frontier. GWM-1 is a blanket term for a trio of autoregression models, each built on top of Runwayâ€™s Gen-4.5 text-to-video generation model and then post-trained with domain-specific data for different kinds of applications. Hereâ€™s what each does. Runwayâ€™s world model announcement livestream video. GWM Worlds GWM Worlds offers an interface for digital environment exploration with real-time user input that affects the generation of coming frames, which Runway suggests can remain consistent and coherent â€œacross long sequences of movement.â€ Read full article Comments

items.title: Instead of fixing WoWâ€™s new floating house exploit, Blizzard makes it official
items.summary: "We all kinda immediately agreed this was way too cool to change."
items.body: Long-time World of Warcraft players have been waiting 21 years for the new in-game housing features that Blizzard officially announced last year and which launched in early access last week . Shortly after that launch, though, players quickly discovered a way to make their houses float high above the ground by exploiting an unintended, invisible UI glitch . Now, Blizzard says that the overwhelming response to that accidental house hovering has been so strong that itâ€™s pivoting to integrate it as an official part of the game. â€œWe were going to fix flying houses to bring them back to terra firma, but you all made such awesome stuff, so we made it possible with the base UI instead,â€ WoW Principal Designer Jesse Kurlancheek posted on social media Tuesday . Lead Producer Kyle Hartline followed up on that announcement with some behind-the-scenes gossip : â€œLike no joke we had an ops channel about how to roll out the float fix but folks shared like 5 of the dopest houses and we all kinda immediately agreed this was way too cool to change,â€ he wrote. Read full article Comments

items.title: Amazon's AI-generated recap tool didn't watch Fallout very closely
items.summary: Amazon's plan to offer AI-generated recaps of Prime Video shows isn't off to a great start. The company's recap of the first season of Fallout features multiple errors, GamesRadar+ writes, including basic facts about the plot of the show. You can watch the recap yourself in the "Extras" section of â€¦

items.title: Disney's deal with OpenAI is about controlling the future of copyright
items.summary: This morning Disney and OpenAI announced a three-year licensing agreement: Starting in 2026, ChatGPT and Sora can generate images and videos incorporating Disney IP, including more than 200 characters from the company's stable of Star Wars, Pixar and Marvel brands. To say these companies make for sâ€¦

items.title: OpenAI releases GPT-5.2 after â€œcode redâ€ Google threat alert
items.summary: Company claims new AI model tops Gemini and matches humans on 70% of work tasks.
items.body: On Thursday, OpenAI released GPT-5.2, its newest family of AI models for ChatGPT, in three versions called Instant, Thinking, and Pro. The release follows CEO Sam Altmanâ€™s internal â€œcode redâ€ memo earlier this month, which directed company resources toward improving ChatGPT in response to competitive pressure from Googleâ€™s Gemini 3 AI model. â€œWe designed 5.2 to unlock even more economic value for people,â€ Fidji Simo, OpenAIâ€™s chief product officer, said during a press briefing with journalists on Thursday. â€œItâ€™s better at creating spreadsheets, building presentations, writing code, perceiving images, understanding long context, using tools and then linking complex, multi-step projects.â€ As with previous versions of GPT-5, the three model tiers serve different purposes: Instant handles faster tasks like writing and translation; Thinking spits out simulated reasoning â€œthinkingâ€ text in an attempt to tackle more complex work like coding and math; and Pro spits out even more simulated reasoning text with the goal of delivering the highest-accuracy performance for difficult problems. Read full article Comments

items.title: '47 Ronin' director found guilty of defrauding Netflix out of $11 million

Carl Rinsch, director of the 2013 Keanu Reeves movie 47 Ronin, now faces up to 90 years in prison. Rinsch began filming the project, White Horse (later renamed Conquest), aâ€¦

NY State Governor Kathy Hochul passed two pieces of legislation on Thursday that forces certain productions to disclose the use of AI-generated performers, and defines rules around how someone's likeness can bâ€¦

The first feature for Disco is called GenTabs, built on Google's Gemini 3 model. GenTabs are interactive widgets created from a mix of user prompts, open tabs and chat history. Theâ€¦

items.title: Images reveal the astonishing complexity of the microscopic world
items.summary: From a dragonfly to marine organisms, photographer Michael Benson zoomed in with powerful scanning electron microscopes to take these extraordinary shots for his book Nanocosmos

items.title: Could the super-rich be cloning themselves? And why would they?
items.summary: Nearly three decades since the remarkable cloning of Dolly the sheep, it has all gone quiet on the human cloning front. Michael Le Page wonders what's happening behind the scenes

items.title: Tigers seem to be bouncing back in remote Sumatran jungle
items.summary: Camera traps in an area of the Leuser rainforest patrolled by NGOs spotted 17 tigers in 2023 and 18 Sumatran tigers in 2024, while surveys elsewhere on the island averaged seven

items.title: Incredible close-up of spider silk wins science photo prize
items.summary: Duelling prairie chickens, a snake-mimicking moth and a once-a-year sunrise at the South Pole feature in the best images from the Royal Society Publishing Photography Competition 2025

items.title: Human challenge trials have never been more popular
items.summary: The ethics of clinical trials that deliberately infect people with a disease aren't clear-cut â€“ but there's a strong case for doing more of them

items.title: Why do I feel lonely even when I'm surrounded by a festive crowd?
items.summary: Feeling alienated in others' company, or "existential isolation", can happen to us all. David Robson digs into the psychological literature for a solution for one reader

items.title: The two standout science-fiction films of 2025
items.summary: From Mickey 17 and M3gan 2.0 to a musical about the end of the world, this was an eclectic year for science-fiction films. Film columnist Simon Ings shares his two breakout hits

items.title: The four best science documentaries of 2025
items.summary: From animal rivals to Jane Goodall's last thoughts, enjoy 2025's best science documentaries, says our TV columnist Bethan Ackerley

items.title: Stop treating your pet like a fur baby â€“ you're damaging its health
items.summary: Pet owners' increasing tendency to see their animals as children rather than dogs or cats can have dire consequences. Owners, and veterinarians, should be wary, warns Eddie Clutton

items.title: The six best science-fiction shows of 2025
items.summary: What were the year's top sci-fi shows? Andor and Severance are still up there, but our TV columnist Bethan Ackerley also has some unexpected tips to share

items.title: Dogs may make us more caring and sociable by changing our microbiome
items.summary: We know that pets influence our microbiome, but scientists have now found that having a dog seems to change this ecosystem in a way that could boost our well-being

items.title: How deliberately giving people illnesses is supercharging medicine
items.summary: The covid-19 pandemic opened the door to once-controversial human challenge trials. Now, volunteers are willingly catching norovirus and influenza to reveal how our immune systems really fight back

items.title: Planned satellite launches could ruin Hubble Space Telescope images
items.summary: More than half a million satellites are planned to launch by the end of the 2030s, and simulations suggest they will have a severe impact on space-based astronomy

items.title: Forming moon may have taken three big impacts early in Earthâ€™s history
items.summary: Conventionally, the moon is thought to have formed during one big impact, but a three-impact model might make more sense

items.title: Jack Sparrow and Henry Turner search for the trident of Poseidon
items.summary: Young Henry Turner seeks out Jack Sparrow to help him locate Poseidon's trident.

items.title: Ancient human artefacts found near caves in Arabian desert
items.summary: Today, the deserts of the Arabian peninsula are inhospitable â€“ but 100,000 years ago, the area was full of animals and ancient humans

items.title: Why quantum mechanics says the past isnâ€™t real
items.summary: The famous double-slit experiment brings into question the very nature of matter. Its cousin, the quantum eraser experiment, makes us question the very existence of time â€“ and how much we can manipulate it

items.title: Black hole entropy hints at a surprising truth about our universe
items.summary: Two clashing ideas about disorder inside black holes now point to the same strange conclusions, and it could reshape the foundations of how we think about space and time

items.title: Can viral relationship tests really tell you about your relationship?
items.summary: Is there any science to viral relationship tests like the bird test, the orange peel theory and the moon phase test? Emily Impett, a professor of psychological and brain sciences at the University of Toronto, has the answers

items.title: Asteroid Bennu carries all the ingredients for life as we know it
items.summary: We knew from prior analyses that a distant asteroid sampled in 2020 carried all but one of the molecules needed to kick-start life, and researchers have just found the missing ingredient: sugar

items.title: Coral reefs have fuelled severe global warming in Earth's past
items.summary: Over the past 250 million years, periods when coral reef growth has peaked have coincided with big rises in sea temperatures

items.title: We now have a greater understanding of how exercise slows cancer
items.summary: Tumour growth is reduced by exercise due to a shift in the bodyâ€™s metabolism that means muscle cells outcompete cancer cells in the race to get sugar to grow

items.title: A sinister, deadly brain protein could reveal the origins of all life
items.summary: We have long struggled to determine how the first living organisms on Earth came together. Now, surprising evidence hints that poorly understood prions may have been the vital missing ingredient

items.title: Man unexpectedly cured of HIV after stem cell transplant
items.summary: A handful of people with HIV have been cured after receiving HIV-resistant stem cells â€“ but a man who received non-resistant stem cells is also now HIV-free

items.title: Cats can overcome fear of water to benefit from aquatic therapy
items.summary: Vets have developed a training protocol to help cats benefit from water-based rehabilitation therapies, in spite of their natural aversion to water

items.title: The best new science fiction books of December 2025
items.summary: From a new collection of shorter fiction by Brandon Sanderson to Simon StÃ¥lenhagâ€™s new work, via a Stranger Things novel, Decemberâ€™s new sci-fi features some compelling and intriguing offerings

items.title: Was a little-known culture in Bronze Age Turkey a major power?
items.summary: Archaeologists have gathered evidence from hundreds of Bronze Age sites in western Turkey that could be remnants of a civilisation that has been largely overlooked

items.title: 'Raise hell' - the fastest bowler you might not have heard of
items.summary: The story of Duncan Spencer, the "frighteningly fast" bowler who could have played for England or Australia.

items.title: Ancient humans took two routes to Australia 60,000 years ago
items.summary: Scientists have long tried to uncover the perilous journey humans took to reach the ancient land mass that now makes up Australia. Now, a genetic study has edged us closer to understanding how and when they achieved this

items.title: Why Googleâ€™s custom AI chips are shaking up the tech industry
items.summary: Google is reportedly in talks to sell its tensor processing units â€“ a type of computer chip specially designed for AI â€“ to other tech companies, a move that could unsettle the dominant chip-maker Nvidia

items.title: Upheavals to the oral microbiome in pregnancy may be behind tooth loss
items.summary: Dental problems often arise or get worse during pregnancy, and a new study hints that rapid changes to the oral microbiome at this time could be at least partly to blame

items.title: Africaâ€™s forests are now emitting more CO2 than they absorb
items.summary: Logging and mining are destroying swathes of the Congo rainforest, with the result that African forests went from being a carbon sink to a carbon source in 2010 to 2017

items.title: Plastic can be programmed to have a lifespan of days, months or years
items.summary: Inspired by natural polymers like DNA, chemists have devised a way to engineer plastic so it breaks down when it is no longer needed, rather than polluting the environment

items.title: Our verdict on sci-fi novel Every Version of You: We (mostly) loved it
items.summary: New Scientist Book Club members share their thoughts on our November read, Grace Chan's Every Version of You

items.title: Read an extract from The Player of Games by Iain M. Banks
items.summary: The New Scientist Book Club is currently reading Iain M. Banks's classic sci-fi novel The Player of Games. In this extract, we meet protagonist Gurgeh for the first time

items.title: Why sci-fi novelist Iain M. Banks was an â€˜astoundingâ€™ world-builder
items.summary: The New Scientist Book Club is currently reading the late Iain M. Banksâ€™s Culture novel The Player of Games. Fellow science fiction author Bethany Jacobs reveals how his work inspired her

items.title: Supermassive dark matter stars may be lurking in the early universe
items.summary: Stars powered by dark matter instead of nuclear fusion could solve several mysteries of the early universe, and we may have spotted the first hints that they are real

items.title: Origin story of domestic cats rewritten by genetic analysis
items.summary: Domestic cats originated in North Africa and spread to Europe in the past 2000 years, according to DNA evidence, while in China a different species of cat lived alongside people much earlier

items.title: Physicists have worked out a universal law for how objects shatter
items.summary: Whether it is a cube of sugar or a chunk of a mineral, a mathematical analysis can identify how many fragments of each size any brittle object will break into

items.title: Emergency response needed to prevent climate breakdown, warn experts
items.summary: Scientists sounded the alarm on the dire consequences of continued inaction at a briefing in London, warning that we could be heading for "unprecedented societal and ecological collapse"

items.title: The 12 best science fiction books of 2025
items.summary: From drowned worlds to virtual utopias via deep space, wild ideas abound in Emily H. Wilson's picks for her favourite sci-fi reads of the year

items.title: COP30: The UN climate summits are no longer fit for purpose
items.summary: The final COP30 agreement fails to even mention fossil fuels. Countries wanting to tackle climate change must not wait for the next meeting to take action

items.title: The quick and easy ways to stay fit this holiday season
items.summary: A chaotic schedule over the holiday season often derails Grace Wadeâ€™s workout routine. But this year she has a planâ€¦

items.title: A revolutionary way to map our bodies is helping cure deadly diseases
items.summary: New tools that create ultra-precise maps of our tissues are transforming our ability to diagnose and cure once-fatal illnesses

items.title: 'Horrific and beautiful' whale rescue image wins photography prize

items.title: What next for friendly foes who see each other 'more than family'?
